content: Hey @T-libs, today in our meeting at 2022-02-23T20:00:00+01:00 i want to talk about all our ongoing 'projects' and go through status updates. I listed a few things i'm working on and a few things i know others are working on, but please add anything that's missing in the agenda: https://hackmd.io/_hy-AKWWT42NEW9yZdpHdA
(also feel free to reorder things if you find something important)
And @T-libs-api here's the agenda for our meeting at 2022-02-23T21:00:00+01:00: https://hackmd.io/RADbXvw_Q0edNMKh6Sn8Iw
@T-libs meeting time! https://meet.jit.si/rust-libs-meeting-ujepnbwg2lzqgt6wvrndwimi
@T-libs-api meeting time https://meet.jit.si/rust-libs-meeting-crxoz2at8hiccp7b3ixf89qgxfymlbwr
Did anyone take the action item to summarize what we'd recommend (extension trait + crater run) to the CStr/CString issue?
OK, I'm writing that summary to the PR now.

Followup from our discussion yesterday in the libs team meeting: https://github.com/rust-lang/libs-team/issues/39, going to go ahead now and work on getting the designated maintainer for netbsd setup and figure out how to make those ping groups
let's not call it designated maintainer but rather developer or expert or something. maintainer kind-of implies r+ rights and more 'ownership' than what we mean
the designated maintainer designation is already part of the template and target tier policy I believe
so I'm mostly using that for consistency with existing documentation
I'm cool with changing it but I don't think we can unilaterally make that decision, since the target tier policy also affects the compiler and infra teams

FWIW, I think while r+ rights are not intended, there is some level of ownership expected -- cleanup work, education work, etc.

Expert to me seems likely to preclude people from signing up; I don't know that developer is quite the right fit, but it might be better.
I think no one is all that beholden to a specific name :)

my thought was that we can have the "designated maintainer" role include R+ rights and mean "the person who gets pinged to review the PRs" and have the ping group be the expert group that could include people beyond the designated maintainers
and we could ping the entire group to get ppl to notice when a relevant PR is opened, but rely on the designated maintainers to actually approve it

I would be reluctant to grant random people who happen to volunteer r+ rights as things stand today, I think, particularly since ideally a good bit of their role is actually putting in some educational material so that the review set for a target doesn't have to be 1-2 people

simulacrum said:

I would be reluctant to grant random people who happen to volunteer r+ rights as things stand today, I think, particularly since ideally a good bit of their role is actually putting in some educational material so that the review set for a target doesn't have to be 1-2 people

wdym by the educational materials?
e.g., links to platform-specific docs
aaah
okay, that's fair, ignore my comment about r+ rights

In this particular case, I would like them to-- rather than "just" saying "yeah this looks good, r+" ideally say something like "Yep, the system libs are documented here (link) -- we should also add X."
(and potentially that link should go in the target docs)

so yea, I don't have a really clear idea of what the breakdown should be then between designated maintainer vs designated expert which leads me to the conclusion that we should definitely only have one or the other

though I'm not convinced its worth the effort to update the docs everywhere and change an established name, I think we can just as easily make it clear that when we say "designated maintainer" we mean "maintainer of the downstream platform"
but, I'm fine either way

@Jane Lusby [she/her] So, in my opinion, I think we do want a "designated maintainer" as someone who can actually make the platform-specific calls for "yes, that's the right API to use" or "no, don't do it that way".
That may be a subset of the people in a ping group for "hey, could we get someone to look at this please?"

Yeah, I agree with wanting someone to make those calls. I think it's important to note that person might not have any Rust experience, and may not even really want to look at code necessarily - I think that part is nice to have but API level assessments can happen without Rust knowledge, which may help expand our possible pool.
okay

gonna try summarizing the concerns so far to help arrive at a consensus

  • worried about calling designated maintainer a "maintainer" and having that be confusing and implying r+ rights
    • suggested designated expert
      • concern over expert causing ppl to feel unqualified and avoid signing up, preference for designated developer
  • wanting to have a someone (unclear on if the terminology here is important) who can make platform specific calls, particularly on api usage, and provide documentation / context on the platforms they represent
  • wanting to include other stakeholders / users / contributors to platforms to give as many people who want notifications access to them
it occurs to me writing this up that the target tier policy includes _requirements_ for how many designated maintainers a platform has to have

so maybe the distinction between the ping group and the people listed in the rustc book's platform support section is that the latter group has a responsibility to show up if nobody else in the ping group does, and if they don't show up they're held accountable / potentially removed as designated maintainers
what do we call the windows ping group?
checking(
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/88924#issuecomment-919311590
its just called the "Windows Group"

so, here's my latest attempt to arrive at consensus:

We could have designated maintainers who are on the hook to show up and answer questions and "make calls" and an associated ping group for anyone who wants to get notified about any ongoing work related to that platform
then we could have the ping group be completely open, and let anyone add themselves to the list
that last bit is less important
as long as its well documented how to get on the list and not onerous

Yeah, that makes sense to me. I'm not sure on 'maintainers' vs. something like 'consultants' :)

I think it makes sense for ping groups to be basically free-for-all; the maintainer list is largely similar, I suspect, though there's a higher bar of commitment expected for those positions.
But I don't care about the name that much either.
yea, I don't expect it to matter in practice but I have no strong attachment to calling them "designated maintainers" vs anything else
my only reason for preferring the former is momentum
